Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2008 02:56PM Watson wrote: Everolimus Blocking mTOR - a central regulator of cancer-cell growth and metabolism The mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) is an intracellular protein that acts as a central regulator of multiple signaling pathways (IGF, EGF, PDGF, VEGF, amino acids) that mediate abnormal growth, proliferation, survival, and angiogenesis in cancer. mTOR is a critical component of the PI3K/AKT pathway, a key signaling pathway that is frequently dysregulated in many cancers. RAD001 is an oral kinase inhibitor that specifically blocks the mTOR protein. By inhibiting cell proliferation, cellular bioenergetics, and angiogenesis, RAD001 may provide clinical benefit to patients with cancer. RAD001 may have antiangiogenic activity due to inhibition of tumoral VEGF production and inhibition of pericyte and endothelial cell proliferation. RAD001 is now being investigated in Phase I to III clinical trials in multiple tumor types, including neuroendocrine tumors, renal cell carcinoma, and colorectal, lung, and breast cancers.

Posts.Content: May 3, 2009 09:59PM Watson wrote: I had a bone marrow biopsy!  I don't have bone mets but was having trouble with dropping red counts several months ago.  My onc doesn't mess around and made me have a bone marrow bx.  It was really no big deal.  I had a freind drive me to the procedure since they gave me pain meds but I was fine.  They had me lay down on my stomach and numbed the area then gave me some deep numbing shots which I didn't feel.  I just felt pressure as they collected marrow.  I left with a bandaid on my butt is all!  I had some achiness for a few days afterward but nothing really bad. My results were great and of course by the next bloodwork my counts were fine.  Well at least we know! If you end up needing this procedure try not to worry, mine was easy. Hugs, Watson

Posts.Content: Aug 10, 2008 09:16PM - edited Aug 11, 2008 03:31PM by Watson It's funny how all the relationships are different. I like my onc a lot.  No, not like that! He is on top of things!  He's the one that retested all my past tumor stuff and found out that i was her2 pos.  He doesn't let things slip past. His nurses don't call back.  They've returned an email or two.   When I was in a trial, the trial nurse answered her cell all the time.  Not so much with his regular nurses.  He has a seperate scheduling assistant and I can get through to her easily as well.   This is going to sound unbelievable but I email or text my onc's cell phone and he gets back right away.  He even answered his cell the one time that I called. And on top of all this, my oncologist is a very compassionate man.  Not to be a downer but I know that one day this man is going to look me in the eye and tell me there is no more that can be done.  With his competence and compassion, I wouldn't want anyone else to deliver that news. Watson

Maybe I'm just a grouch, but I can't stand large groups of people waving pink crap saying Yay, look at us!  I felt this way long before I was dx with mets.  (You can look up past rants)  Most of these organizations are giving the majority of $$ to provided mammograms to women who can't afford them.  Very Noble.  Not knocking it.  BUT THEN WHAT?  They're in here with us wondering what next. The 'Pink Parties' make the general public feel better.  I don't want people to feel better about us.  It needs to get publicly ugly before anything is going to really happen. They didn't make Aids perceived as a cute little disease.  It scared the bejeesus out of everyone.  And guess what, they came up with meds that keep people alive forever.  Wow, where are these rants coming from?  lol I'm just saying I don't want to play into the "pink and happy therefore no problem" theory.  The end, for now, lol Watson

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2008 12:48PM - edited Aug 22, 2008 12:49PM by Watson I guess it really just boils down to the individual oncologist.  I started out with general oncologist.  She's the one that diagnosed me as triple negative and it turns out I was her2 pos (just slightly) all along.  I was never blown away by her care.  She was nice enough and all, but I switched to MD Anderson and have a breast oncologist in a breast clinic on a breast floor!  I have had nothing but great things to say about my new onc and my care.  So as you can see, it's not necessarily where they work but the oncoloist involved.  My advice is to be with someone who is very knowledgable and yet compassionate enough to give you bad news in a way you can tolerate. Hugs, Watson

Posts.Content: Watson wrote: Hello fellow metsters and concerned others, I was dx with mets just under a month ago.  I can honestly say I don't think I felt any pain, SOB, etc.  That is until a few days ago.  I am on my off week from Xeloda. I am having a dull ache/pain in spots on my back.  It feels like someone is poking me with a broom handle.  (not that I ever remember being poked with a broom handle, but was watching husband do yard work yesterday and came up with that analogy)  It doesn't get worse if I breathe in heavy or exhale. And while my breathing is still clear and no SOB, I am having a little cough about 5 to 10 times a day.  No big deal, but it is there.  It may have been that way even before dx.  My voice sounds like I have a slight congestion but again no problem with breathing or inhaling/exhaling.  It's just worrisome that I'm getting these issues while on Xeloda.  You'd think any symptoms would be getting better, not beginning! I have an appt with onc tomorrow for bloodwork, yada yada so of course I will mention this newest development.  But why wait to talk to a professional when I can whine and obsess with the people that  REALLY know what's going on? And by the way,  I had someone ask me if chatting with "internet people" was my new thing.  I told her yes it was.  I was starting off with women w/ breast cancer and was going to work myself up to men with Ferrari's! Any thoughts?  (About the lung problems, not the men w/ Ferrari's!) Love, Watson I'd rather laugh with the sinners than cry with the saints. - Billy Joel Dx 1/29/2008, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Watson wrote:  Howdy.  I posted elsewhere about my next treatment options.  Here is a possibility.  Anyone else have this presented to them? Everolimus Blocking mTOR - a central regulator of cancer-cell growth and metabolism The mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) is an intracellular protein that acts as a central regulator of multiple signaling pathways (IGF, EGF, PDGF, VEGF, amino acids) that mediate abnormal growth, proliferation, survival, and angiogenesis in cancer. mTOR is a critical component of the PI3K/AKT pathway, a key signaling pathway that is frequently dysregulated in many cancers. RAD001 is an oral kinase inhibitor that specifically blocks the mTOR protein. By inhibiting cell proliferation, cellular bioenergetics, and angiogenesis, RAD001 may provide clinical benefit to patients with cancer. RAD001 may have antiangiogenic activity due to inhibition of tumoral VEGF production and inhibition of pericyte and endothelial cell proliferation. RAD001 is now being investigated in Phase I to III clinical trials in multiple tumor types, including neuroendocrine tumors, renal cell carcinoma, and colorectal, lung, and breast cancers. I'd rather laugh with the sinners than cry with the saints. - Billy Joel Dx 1/29/2008, Stage IV, mets, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
